title: When will a Carnival Cruise Line cruise next depart from the continental U.S.?
preds: Well...this is less worthwhile than I hoped, but I am here, so submitting.  Based on time's passage.
"no Carnival cruises will be setting sail until after March 31" https://www.businessinsider.com/cruise-lines-2021-sailing-plans
No tickets available for any potential voyages on their website.
Covid ship travel will be a problem for the industry for some time.

"Carnival Cruise Line recently cancelled its entire February schedule. Now, it plans to restart operations in early March, using most of its fleet." https://www.cruiseindustrynews.com/cruise-news/24032-when-the-major-cruise-lines-plan-to-restart-service-3.html
Certain this will not happen before 16 January given it's now December and it's not on the horizon.

Carnival Cruise Line has provided a major update that includes another delay for the new Mardi Gras cruise ship and cruises in February out of three homeports. This comes as the cruise line continues to work on making sure operations can resume safely in 2021.
https://www.cruisehive.com/carnivals-new-cruise-ship-delayed-more-cancellations/43732 Rien ne va plus.

"The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention published a Level 4 travel notice on Saturday advising that 'all people' should avoid travel on cruise ships worldwide because 'the risk of COVID-19 on cruise ships is very high.' ... This month, the cruise industry extended its voluntary operational pause through the end of the year ...  Carnival has canceled all sailings in U.S. waters until February 2021." https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/cruises/2020/11/22/cdc-advises-against-cruise-travel-all-people-should-avoid-worldwide/6382599002/

I'm not going to list all the different cruise lines dates, but pretty much nothing will happen even before the spring 2021. https://eu.usatoday.com/story/travel/cruises/2020/11/18/carnival-cruise-line-ships-wont-sail-us-waters-until-february/6338325002/

"Carnival canceled all of its planned sailings in U.S. waters until February and some sailings into March, the line said in a release provided by spokesperson Vance Gulliksen earlier this week ... All cruises from U.S. homeports between Jan.1 and Jan. 31 have been canceled." https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/cruises/2020/11/18/carnival-cruise-line-ships-wont-sail-us-waters-until-february/6338325002/

What could possibly go wrong? Oh yeah...
https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/nov/12/caribbean-cruise-ship-coronavirus-seadream

Another large outbreak of the virus seems like it will push back things like this for a while. Some cruises scheduled before the 16th but seems unlikely it will happen. For it to be safe they would probably need some sort of testing and quarantine period prior to sailing and I don't see that happening logistically.

Updated 20201112 @Annieinak @Econja2018 Although Carnival Cruise Line has 23 cruises scheduled (https://bit.ly/35omdAR) for departure from Continental US before 16 January 2021, I am still hesitant to change my forecast based on a) Judge P Seitz's court order (see 20201027 forecast), b) the 60 day prior notification period in the CDC 'conditional sailing order' and c) the possibility the CDC will issue another no sail order as a result of the increase in new Covid-19 cases across USA. In 4-5 days time, the CDC 60 day prior notification period will effectively close the question to the possibility of a mock cruise meeting the last requirement of the question. The news that a passenger on a SeaDream 1 cruise, which embarked at Bridgetown, tested positive for Covid-19 (https://bit.ly/36wr964) is not going to help the industry restart cruising. Increased bookings for 2021 / 22 since the CDC's conditional sailing order may drop ff again now.

Cruising won’t resume in U.S. waters until 2021, with lines renewing a voluntary suspension
The world’s largest cruise industry trade association says ships with passengers will not return to U.S. waters this year.
By Shannon McMahon
November 3
https://www.washingtonpost.com/travel/2020/11/03/cruises-2021-voluntary-suspension
Cruise ships will not return to U.S. waters with passengers onboard until 2021, Cruise Lines International Association (CLIA), announced Tuesday. The group has extended through Dec. 31 a voluntary suspension of U.S. operations that expired Saturday. CLIA includes Carnival Cruises, Disney Cruise Line, Norwegian Cruise Line and Royal Caribbean, and makes up 95 percent of the global cruising industry. CLIA said in a news release that the continued suspension of operations “will provide additional time to align the industry’s extensive preparation of health protocols with the implementation requirements under the CDC’s Framework for Conditional Sailing and Initial Phase

Published November 3
Carnival Corp. cancels North American cruises through end of 2020
https://www.foxbusiness.com/lifestyle/carnival-cancels-north-american-cruises-end-2020

If I'm reading this correctly, SOMEONE found time to sign a "framework conditional sail order" on November 4th. https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/cruise/index.html

Hence my amended forecast. However, a strict interpretation of the question still implies a mock cruise would be meet the requirement between 1 Jan and 16 Jan 2021.

I was a bit hung up on if the simulated cruise with volunteer passengers will meet the requirements of thos question.  I have decided ot would not because who would pay to go through the arduous process of being selected as a volunteer?  
With all the requirements the cruise lines will need 60 days to prep to get the simulated cruise. Then they need a CDC approval.  That is how the CDC  will control the speed that this actually sets sail. The back and forth can delay sailing a long time.  To me it makes sense, that the CDC capitulates to end the No Sail Order as Trump wanted, knowing it can still control based on its administartive requirements. If Trump loses Nov 3 then in effect the CDC will just ignore him till Biden takes office (call it Deep State or Fealities of Beuracracy).  If  Trimp wins then CDC delays until it can't no more.

October 30, 2020 Update On October 30, 2020, CDC issued a Framework for Conditional Sailing Order. This Order is effective upon signature and will soon be published in the Federal Register. This Order shall remain in effect until the earliest of The expiration of the Secretary of Health and Human Services’ declaration that COVID-19 constitutes a public health emergency,
The CDC Director rescinds or modifies the order based on specific public health or other considerations, or

https://cruiseradio.net/carnival-begins-restaffing-cruise-ships-hope-december-2020-return/ Carnival Cruise Line is beginning the process of restaffing its ships as part of their plan for a phased relaunch that could begin as early as December.

It seems that the cards are really stacked against this, with the biggest cards being a resurgence of cases and the CDC's likely response to that situation.  The only saving grace will be a vaccine;  I wonder if Carnival has invested in shots???

Updated 20201102 The "Framework for Conditional Sailing Order for Cruise Ships" released by the CDC (https://bit.ly/2JwjGfq and https://www.cdc.gov/quarantine/pdf/CDC-Conditional-Sail-Order_10_30_2020-p.pdf) is complex and thus not a simple 'you can begin sailing' statement. The word 'conditional' belies some of the factors, more accurately explained here: https://bit.ly/3kV0HZU and here https://bit.ly/3kS8cRe . The requirement to apply for the "Conditional Sailing Certificate at least 60 days before they want to resume sailing" effectively pushing possible sailings by Carnival to at least 2 Jan 2021 as of today.  Carnival's Aida has suspended sailings in Europe for the month of November due to increasing coronavirus outbreaks. This will simply add to the company's cash flow problems and may pressure Carnival Cruise Line to consider sailings from Continental US sooner rather than later. However, Judge Seitz's court order (see below) and the CDC's new requirements make it difficult to see how the company can resume commercial sailings from continental US any time soon.  One important  aspect to the question "When will a Carnival Cruise Line cruise next depart from the continental U.S.?" is to define what is meant by the question. In the strictest of interpretations, a mock cruise as defined by the new CDC requirements would answer the question in the affirmative. Thus, in this case, I have left my current forecast as is because that is a real possibility. @Anneinak; do you have any views on this changed scenario? Updated 20201027 The CDC recently issued a Level 3 Warning to US citizens to avoid non essential travel by boat / cruise ship. See https://bit.ly/34xScyb. This is noteworthy simply because it is unusual for CDC to issue warnings for a specific transport type. Cruise ships and boats in this case. Carnival Cruise Line has the additional burden of complying with the Southern District of Florida Court Order issued by Judge Patricia Seitz on 21 October 2020. This relates to the Probation Order given by the court for environmental pollution transgressions in 2017 & 2018. See https://bit.ly/34yuBxm. In brief, 30 days notice should be given to the court prior to a Carnival Corp ship entering US waters and a certificate of compliance with the probation order must be submitted by the CEO. There is some leeway for Carnival in the order in that a company vessel "that anticipates entering U.S. Waters before December 31, 2020, the Company shall immediately notify the Interested Parties, CAM, and TPA,and shall provide the information required by this Order no less than 7 days after the date of entry." See also https://bit.ly/34vf0OX @Anneinak : The shrinking patch of high ground is getting smaller! I moved to 85% for not before Jan 16 based on the above, the increasing number of new cases in the northern hemisphere, the diminishing likelihood of a widely available vaccine before mid-jan 2021. However, CDC will update in the next 14 days and that plus the election may give us / me a better outlook? There is still a small probability of a Carnival Cruise Line boat departing US between 1 Dec 2020 and 15 Jan 2021; basically, the company needs cash flow IMO

Update: "Last week, a District Judge for the Southern District of Florida said she would propose that Carnival Corporation present a 60-day environmental plan for each ship in their fleet before they would be allowed to cruise in North America ... But the Miami Herald reports that Judge Patricia Seitz has since walked back her decision, saying that Carnival would need to provide the appropriate certifications 30 days before sailing ... Theoretically, this provides the company with time to abide by the Judge’s ruling and still be prepared for a December return ... All of Carnival’s ships have been out of U.S. territorial waters since June. The current no-sail order by the Centers for Disease Control is expected to expire on October 31, 2020." https://cruiseradio.net/judges-ruling-clears-path-for-carnival-december-1-sailing/

Carnival still has dozens of cruises scheduled in Nov-Dec-Jan but if COVID gets as bad as I think it will, and if the CDC has its way (over DJT's objections), November & December cruises may be cancelled.

They've already scrubbed everything through 31 December.  Presumably it takes a while to get the rolling stock ready to go again, and then to round up enough customers who are sufficiently foolhardy and well heeled to make a fist of it.  Next issue may be locating a country that will let several hundred unmasked denizens of CoroNation disembark.  They'll probably persuade at least one that needs the money badly enough.   If they can't, they will start with Cruises To Nowhere.  They will leave out of Miami (which will close this Q if it's before the 16th) and sail aimlessly around for a week or so.  Every few days some crew members will put on straw hats and go out on deck to sell baskets.  This will add an air of verisimilitude to the cruise experience.  To further this end, albeit unwittingly, a recently retired gentleman and his wife will complain about the food and the weather.  They will be from New Jersey.  He will be wearing short pants; she will be wearing a muumuu.  Bon voyage!

Well, this will be an easy way to know when Carnival plans on actually resuming sailing (while also making it more unlikely that such sailing will happen this year) — "A federal judge said she plans to require Carnival Corp. to certify that each of its cruise ships is compliant with its probation obligations 60 days before those ships reenter U.S. waters to restart cruises ... The forthcoming order from U.S. District Judge for the Southern District of Florida Patricia Seitz could inhibit the company’s plans to resume cruise operations in the United States on Dec. 1. Seitz made the announcement at a status conference Friday in the company’s ongoing criminal case for environmental crimes ... The order — if it is made official — will require ships to notify her 60 days in advance of reentering U.S. waters, Seitz said, and each ship will need a certification from CEO Arnold Donald regarding its environmental compliance status." https://www.miamiherald.com/news/business/tourism-cruises/article246504540.html

This is a depressing question for several reasons, the primary being that it should've been settled on September 30th when the CDC elected to extend the 'no sail' order until February. This decision was overruled by the White House, which likely feared consequences in the swing state of Florida if it were to be implemented. Now, however, we are perhaps days away from reaching peak daily COVID numbers for the year, are back to 1000 people dying each day from the virus, and still have no mitigation or reactionary plans in place on a national level. Therefore, this question is no longer about what is right, but which is more powerful: the scientific community or the President of the United States? The right decision is clear, but the wrong decision is possible. Carnival itself has decided not to resume until December, but its impossible to say what the situation might look like at that point.

Two factors that will affect the date:
1. Will DT be re-elected? If yes, then the administration will again put pressure on CDC to open the cruise lines
2. Will the cases fall enough so that CDC by itself can decide to reopen the cruise lines. I see very little possibility of any of the above 2, so unlikely that cruise will sail anytime soon

https://www.cruisehive.com/is-there-any-hope-of-a-carnival-cruise-this-year/42638 ". . . What will happen to cruises booked from the homeports in December, and is it even reasonable to think that Carnival will be cruising this year?
. . .
The embarkation procedures, setting up online check-in systems, ensuring that these are thoroughly tested to ensure they work will take a lot of time and effort. There need to be luggage sanitation stations, where everyone’s luggage can be disinfected. Most importantly, cruise lines will need to train hundreds of people in conducting COVID-19 tests for thousands of cruise passengers, and ensure these tests are back within the hour. Onboard the implementation ranges from setting up social distancing throughout the vessel, measuring how far tables are apart, setting up sunbeds with social distancing in mind, and setting up a digital restaurant system that will work on everyone’s smartphone. The list is endless. . . .  There is no-one that knows for sure that the U.S. authorities and the CDC will approve these procedures. . . . the fact remains that the final say on whether cruising in the United States resumes lies solely with the CDC and Director Robert Redfield. The cruise lines have been making plans to resume cruising for many months now. And each time they have been stopped by the CDC. It has been made very clear by Director Redfield that he would rather see a No Sail Order until February. If it wasn’t for the White House’s veto on the matter, the No Sail Order until February would be in place.
. . . 
Hypothetically, if the CDC announces tomorrow that cruising is allowed immediately, how long would it take Carnival to have ships crewed and ready to go? Most Carnival ships have crew members that come from such countries . . .  which have strict measures in place.
. . . 
From the moment the crew member gets the call to travel, it will be at least two weeks to the moment they fly. If crew members are allowed onboard, another Quarantine and COVID test awaits them. Only then will the crew be allowed to go to work and start training for all the new procedures. This means a minimum of one month, but most likely much longer, to get the crew ready. The one month does not account for the possibility of infection amongst crew members. So, Will I Be Able To Take A Carnival Cruise In December? . . .  Yes, you might be able to take a cruise. However, this depends on so many factors, which all need to have people willing to make the decisions needed, that it seems unlikely at best.

"Carnival Cruise Line announced Monday morning they would be canceling all cruises scheduled for the month of November 2020 ... Carnival Cruise Line had originally hoped to resume sailings on November 1 with six ships operating out of two Florida ports ... Despite this latest setback, Carnival Corporation CEO Arnold Donald earlier this week said that he was 'optimistic' that guests would be able to cruise from American ports before the end of 2020. How optimistic? He said that on a scale of 1-5, he was weighing in somewhere between 4.5 and 4.9." https://cruiseradio.net/carnival-cancels-all-november-2020-sailings-hopeful-december/

Cruises currently scheduled for December from those two homeports remain in place for the time being while Carnival evaluates options. "

The CDC extended it’s no sail order for cruise operations until October 31st due to the pandemic.
The cruise line said that made making any plans for a November re-start impossible.
[...]
Carnival does say its Florida based cruises are still expected to sail again in December."
https://www.wltz.com/2020/10/13/carnival-cancels-cruises-thru-november/

I feel like I'm standing on a shrinking little patch of high ground and the water is rising!   Reasoning:
- a lot of demand for cruises may be building up 
- demand may peak around the holidays.  For some, a holiday cruise is a family tradition.
-Carnival doesn't make money if it's not doing cruises
-the CDC is extending its ban only 30 days at a time, currently through Nov 1st.
-DJT wants the CDC to lift its restrictions. OTOH
-COVID is likely to get worse, 
-passengers may be reluctant to book for fear of last minute cancellation by Carnival
-Carnival may decide to not sail for lack of crew or bookings, or fear of liability
-CDC may extend its cruise ban

Updated 20201011 A financial update from Carnival Corp provides some hope for Carnival Cruise Lines to resume cruises ex continental US before the end of 2020 - https://prn.to/3iPvgOG. As of today, Carnival Cruise Line lists the first departures from continental US from 17 December 2020 . Most cruise lines appear to be restarting cruise operations initially on limited 'test' cruises with crew and perhaps some limited company staff to simulate operations and to check and test training, new systems and procedures etc. CDC's decision to expire or extend the no sail order at te end of October will be the defining factor.

I am emending my prior forecasts on the basis the cruise industry has worked hard, spent time, effort and money in preparation of cruising restarting from continental US. In spite of my view that there will be limited demand from paying passengers, there will undoubtedly be passengers for Carnival to at least trial one cruise from either of  the two US ports they have earmarked for the restart (see previous forecasts). Recent government involvement at local and federal level including CDC involvement and discussion with the industry bode well for a restart on 1 Nov 2020 when the current CDC no sail order expires. See https://bit.ly/34DUlqK

"Arnold Donald, the CEO of Carnival Corp., expects that the company's cruise lines will be sailing by the end of the year in U.S. waters after a more-than-seven-month pause in operations ... While both the CDC's 'no-sail' order and Cruise Lines International Association's (CLIA) voluntary suspension are scheduled to end on Oct. 31, two of Carnival's Corp's biggest lines have canceled cruises beyond that date." https://www.usatoday.com/story/travel/cruises/2020/10/08/carnival-corp-expects-cruise-us-2020-a-way-go-forward/5904240002/

Carnival Corp. posted a loss of 2.9bn USD with virtually no (~37mn (!)USD) revenues for Q3 2020. The good news is, they still have some 8bn USD in liquidity before burnout, at this pace around April/May 2021. Yet, the sooner the cruises start again, the sooner the bleeding is stopped.

Mobile Alabama on Nov 3 is off the cards. From here I think it's more likely that the CDC will push a no sail order far into 2021, especially with the President graduating from Covid school over the weekend.

Carnival seems to be deferring to CDC. The CDC Wanted to extend the NSO until Feb, but the trump administration prevented them: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/30/health/covid-cruise-ships.html The administration likely wanted to have some ships depart before the election, but that gives a window of 3 days in general, and not possible for Carnival. The earliest date still available on Carnival's site is Nov 21st. Still if the major factor that is preventing Carnival from launching is CDC's approval, we might not see the CDC able to extend the NSO again under this administration. I am bumping the chance for sailing Between 24 November 2020 and 15 January 2021 up to 20%

Carnival's website doesn't have any cruises scheduled for November. The earliest cruise that can be booked is mid-December (search by month on the website below): https://www.carnival.com/cruise-search/#?layout=grid&numAdults=2&pageNumber=1&pageSize=8&showBest=true&sort=fromprice&useSuggestions=true While it remains possible they will sail before 1/16/21, it seems highly unlikely given the CDC's cruise ban was just extended until the end of October and given the current positive and transmission rates, it may likely be extended again through the end of the year.

Updated 20201003 Carnival announces cancellation of all cruises from continental US through to December 2020 except from Miami and Port Canaveral. Current cruises for the rest of 2020, after 31 Oct, are still subject to confirmation, See https://bit.ly/2So4lia Updated 20201002 Carnival announced it has cancelled all sailings in 2020 from continental US except for possible sailings from Miami and Port Canaveral in Florida (https://bit.ly/30nP0Cr) albeit there is no certainty about sailings from those to ports yet. To quote; "According to Carnival's statement, the fates of 2020 cruises booked from Port Canaveral and Miami are also uncertain. The company says it is "focusing its initial return to service from those two homeports" but scheduling is still unknown. Year-end cruises originating at those cities still technically have the green light from the company, but Carnival is urging people already booked on them to cancel for "future cruise credit" or a refund because of the uncertainty around when voyages will actually resume." Hence, there is a small possibility of a sailing between 1 Jan 2021 an 15 Jan 2021. Further to my forecast of 20200831 and updates to 20200927, I am amending with am increase in the likelihood of a (take note "a) Carnival Cruise Line cruise departing from continental US  between November 24 2020 and 15 January 2021 based on a) the extension of the No Sail order by CDC to 31 October 2020 (https://bit.ly/33lkVWo) and b) the apparent conflict between CDC and The White House which apparently overruled CDC's proposed extension of the No Sail Order to February 2021 (https://bit.ly/3jp6Rk3 and https://nyti.ms/30r0lBI). The third paragraph of CDC's extension press release indicates that CDC is closely monitoring international cruise activity and any potential outbreaks on cruises. This has occurred in Europe (https://bbc.in/2EQQjCB). However, the numbers are not significant and with the possibility of a vaccine by year end, the CLIA presenting a plan for safe cruising, the Safe Sail Act proposed by Scott & Rubio, the appeal to Miami-Dade by cruise lines in Sept and the dire financial position of the cruise lines and Carnival in particular, there is mounting  pressure to resume cruises from Continental US before 16 January 2021.

"The White House has blocked a new order from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to keep cruise ships docked until mid-February ... Updated 20200927 Although there has been some more positive media coverage about the restart of cruising from continental USA, I do not think tere will be a rush from paying customers to cruise before January 15 2021 for the following reasons:
i) the covid-19 pandemic is still a concern as new case numbers increase
ii) a significant proportion of past paying cruise customers are older (see survey by CLIA - https://bit.ly/3cApnmZ) making up 33% or more and hence likely to be more vulnerable to covid-19 infection
iii) it is still unclear if a vaccine will be available before Jan 16 and if this will provide sufficient protection to cruise passengers
iv) there is still the fear that a cruise ship is possibly a breeding zone for the covid-19 virus once a passenger or crew member is infected. Updated 20200922 Carnival is terminating or not renewing contracts of up to 7,000 staff which, in the 2020 staff reductions, will amount to > 20% of its workforce. The company's cash burn is considerable and one wonders if the company can survive should the CDC not lift the 'no sail' order on 30 Sept. See https://bit.ly/3hRcs16 Updated 20200921: Carnival Cruise Line has increased the number of ships it is selling from 14 to 18. It cites cash flow, operating efficiencies and health and safety as being the reasons. Equally, further cancellations / postponements by both Carnival and other cruise lines have been announced (See https://youtu.be/dvAaRTnGW1U). Three Carnival cruises have been postponed from Miami, Tampa and new Orleans until March 13, March 19 and Apr 29 respectively, i.e. after the period of this forecast. Senators R Scott & M Rubio have introduced the Set Safely Sail Act on 20200916  in an effort move forward the resumption of cruising from continental USA. (See https://bit.ly/3kBeqUV). Whether this Act will move through the system rapidly is yet to be soon. It is also questionable whether it will be processed before the CDC's moratorium date of 30 September and if so, whether it could bypass the CDC ruling. However, bearing in mind that all members of the Cruise Lines International, of which Carnival is a member, have voluntarily suspended cruising ex USA until 31 October 2020, the Set Sail Safely Bill may still have some impact on the resumption of cruising from continental USA. Updated 20200912 The following article, https://bit.ly/2Rkk5SP, shows the leading cruise lines are putting pressure in Miami-Dade to restart the industry. My earlier rationale below is still applicable. However, my 5% forecast for the 24 Nov 2020 - 15 Jan 2021 period holds for the moment but may be revised should this look the more likely time frame. Updated 20200911 Further to my forecasts below, a factor in my rationale has been the likely reticence of potential paying passengers from booking cruises until they feel safe in the environment, both on ship, getting to the ship and the general environment. This appears to be confirmed in recent spending studies done in Europe and USA. See https://reut.rs/33lM5uO Par 7 which indicates that higher income people are not spending freely. Cruise lines draw most of the paying passengers from higher income groups. Thus, lack of bookings in addition to health, transport, regulatory and logistics challenges make it unlikely  cruises from continental USA will depart before 16 January 2021.  Updated 20200909: One aspect previously mentioned in my forecasts has been the unlikelihood of paying passengers booking cruises with the period of this forecast simply because of concerns over health and the history of cruise ships being infected by covid-19 in the early stages of the global pandemic. Undoubtedly cruise line companies, Carnival Line included, have been hoping for is the early arrival of a vaccine. However, in the light of the media coverage recently regarding pharma companies a) pledging to ensure safety and b) the potentially severe reaction of an intrial patient on the AstraZenica - Oxford Univerity Phase 3 trial (see BBC https://bit.ly/342xeHO), potentially paying passengers are likely to take a more hesitant wait and see approach prior to booking a cruise. Additionally, once a vaccine is available, how quickly can potentially paying passengers get vaccinated and how quickly can cruise lines get crews vaccinated? This will be another limitation in the period of this forecast. Further to my forecasts of July 27, Aug 23 & 28, my changed forecast is the result of:
a) CDC has issued a further moratorium on cruising until Sept 31; CDC has called for public comment on reopening the industry; See https://bit.ly/2ZwosOZ. This closes on 20200921, barely a week before the current suspension ends. As of 20200912, > 3750 submissions have been made. Is it possible CDC will assess, check verify all these and make a decision to restart the industry in a week? Unlikely in my view.  
b) amended CDC rules for cruise ship crews and the repatriation of crews to home countries has caused most cruise companies to withdraw ships from USA waters in order to repatriate crews and enable crews to avoid what in effect is quartanting in their cabin on board the ships
c) in addition to repatriating crews, cruise line companies, Carnival included, needed 'storage' for ships and / or maintenance. This was cheaper in European waters or elsewhere.
d) in the light b) & c), the number of cruise ships has fallen from around 120 in Feb 2020 cruising or located  to USA waters to around 30 in Aug 2020. According to a report on 10 Aug 2020, Carnival confirmed that none of its 90 ships are in USA waters at present.  See https://bit.ly/3hRju6U from Forbes. See https://bit.ly/2EUmIIc and https://hrld.us/34OUtFz (Miami Herald)  On 27 Aug 2020, CDC issued an update advising people to defer travel on cruise ships (https://bit.ly/3gLf543).  In the light of the above, the fact Carnival Cruise Line has no ships currently in USA waters, the apparent increase in covid 19 cases in many parts of the world in the recent weeks, the imminent arrival of winter, the tropical storms in and around the USA continent, I do not see a huge demand for cruising from the target market before 16 January 2021, a mere four and half months away. An additional factor cruise operators, including Carnival, take cognisance of is that air travel is extremely limited currently and may stay that way for some time. This makes it either impossible or very dificult, expensive and inconvenient for many potential paying passengers to meet ships or return home from cruises. As of the time of writing, Carnival released a press release cancelling cruises for its Princess Lines , including the Island Princess early 2021 sailngs from continental USA. (See https://bit.ly/3hPUAo0) Hence, my above revised forecast.

I don’t expect any cruises to depart from the continental USA by end of year. Carnival are selling a number of boats right now to sustain a prolonged market downturn.
For this to happen (i.e. any cruise to depart in the US) two things need to happen:
- a sustained reduction in covid cases to be observed. Right now we see a surge in cases, especially Florida which is a popular departure location. Such a reduction may occur in a month or two (October) or the autumn weather might even bring a second wave of pandemic, thus delaying the cruise industry restart. I assign 33% chance that October time brings a definitive reduction in covid cases in the US.
- second condition is that other countries (Caribbean for southern departures or Canada, for Seattle departures) observe a similar improvement in covid cases, that allows them to open their ports. I assign the same probability to that.
- finally, consumer confidence has to have returned to confining themselves in cruise ships. We are talking about relatively wealthy retirees. They will take their time to accept to take this risk. This means that with even a 40% capacity, the cruise ship is unlikely to be economic to sail. I assign a 50% chance to demand being there for at least one ship to sail, even when the 33% above has occurred.
Overall, I think this bring the cumulative probability to about 17% for anything before January.

Social distancing is next to impossible on a vessel.  Passageways, deck space, dining, embarkation etc. present all sorts of logistical difficulties.  I also cannot imagine any port, foreign or domestic allowing passengers to visit shore attractions. That means only a cruise that circles around the ocean, depressing overall demand for cruises. As for the promise of rapid testing, the current false negative rate combined with even a 25% occupancy rate put the potential numbers of infected, but asymptomatic passengers and crew at levels that are simply untenable. From https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2020/06/200610094112.htm  Johns Hopkins examination of False Negative Rates
The researchers estimated that those tested with SARS-CoV-2 in the four days after infection were 67% more likely to test negative, even if they had the virus. When the average patient began displaying symptoms of the virus, the false-negative rate was 38%. The test performed best eight days after infection (on average, three days after symptom onset), but even then had a false negative rate of 20%, meaning one in five people who had the virus had a negative test result.

f there is accurate rapid testing is available (and we should see much progress in this area in the next few months), then they could test everyone before they board and keep everyone at sea for the entire cruise. The cruise lines are going to be aggressive in trying to get on the water - even if they have to run a ship at 25% or 50% and test everyone, they will try and make it happen. And the US government will likely try to have a "feel good" win like a cruise ship sailing prior to the election.
